awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Research Initiation: Writing Education Initiating Identity Transformation in Engineering Students-The Wri2tes Project
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to better prepare engineers for professional work by understanding how experiences of learning to write in school help develop students' capacities for engineering judgement and their identities as responsible professionals. The engineering disciplines are rigorous in their application of scientific principles, and these principles are directly addressed in undergraduate engineering classrooms. However, engineers are also called to make decisions that implicitly account for complex criteria, including the welfare of those who use or are impacted by the systems they design and the economic needs of their employers. As a result, in many ways engineering is an art that requires practitioners to routinely navigate difficult tradeoffs that require professional judgments. These judgments include often-conflicting economic, ethical, social, and value-based dimensions, requiring engineers to make well-reasoned decisions for the benefit of society. In order to best serve the public, engineers need to communicate their judgments to engineers, non-specialists, clients, and a variety of others. One key goal in all such interactions will be to convey themselves as competent professionals; either as insiders to other engineers, or as authoritative experts to those seeking their advice. The art of engineering, in short, is tightly bound to the negotiation of engineering identity: engineers must be able to practice engineering as art and develop sound judgments that balance complex, competing objectives or constraints, and they must simultaneously convey these judgments in ways that will help them identify-and be recognized as-engineers. Despite this tight connection, however, little work to date has investigated the relationship between the writing engineering students do and the development of engineering identities, particularly in terms of engineering judgment. 
This project addresses this gap by exploring how students' experiences with writing shape their identification with the engineering profession and the way they convey engineering judgments to better ensure that tomorrow's engineering workforce will best serve the needs of public. To investigate the ways students produce engineer identities in written artifacts through which they expect to be recognized as engineers, the project employs a two-phase qualitative case study; Phase 1 uses semi-structured interviews and analyses of student work to explore engineering identity production in writing, and Phase 2 uses those results to design and study assignments intended to more effectively foster engineering identity production in writing. The study is grounded in Gee's use of identity as an analytic lens, Tonso's identity production theory, and Lea and Street's academic literacy approach. In Phase 1, the case studies will focus on the ways students produce engineer identities through their written projects. Course documents (including assignments and related material) as well as instructors' autoethnographic field notes on implementation will provide contextual data for the case. In Phase 2, the insights from the initial cases will be used to design appropriate teaching tools and approaches. Few studies in engineering identity have investigated the role that navigating difficult tradeoffs in writing plays in students' engineering identity construction. In addition, few investigators have examined the ways in which the artifacts students produce reflect the choices students must negotiate during their professional identity development and production. This study contributes to our knowledge of how a critical professional practice-writing-contributes to the development of students' holistic engineering identities in ways that best prepare them to develop products and systems that meet societies needs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overall objective of this project was to explore the ways that undergraduate students participate in the construction and communication of engineering judgments in writing. Written communication skills are crucial to the future professional success of engineering students; however, many employers express dissatisfaction with students' abilities to communicate in writing. Moreover, most engineers work on teams, and written communications are often the medium through which information is exchanged between team members. At the same time, engineering practice is characterized by professional judgment. In practice, engineers make complex tradeoffs among competing demands, determine scopes of work, evaluate the feasibility of available actions, connect tangible real-world systems to their mathematical calculations, and so much more.

Despite the centrality of both written communications and engineering judgment to engineering practice, few investigators have explored the ways that engineering students construct judgments in writing. Our project proceeded by first synthesizing a theorization of engineering judgment at the intersection of engineering identity, naturalistic decision making, and the engineering work context characterized by uncertainty, ambiguity, and complexity. Our theorization repositions engineering judgment from something that an individual does alone, to something that emerges from the interactions of several professionals working together on a team. We define engineering judgment as a holistic participatory capacity situated within the complex, open-ended, socio-technical contexts of engineering work that integrates the cognitive processes underpinning naturalistic decision making with the cultural and discursive production of professional identities needed to effectively negotiate judgments.

Having defined engineering judgment, we set out to better understand: 1) "How do undergraduate systems engineering students participate in the construction of engineering judgments?"; and, 2) "What are the choices undergraduate systems engineering students make in their writing to communicate the engineering judgments they have made?" We conducted a constructivist qualitative case study to answer these research questions. We collected 10 semi-structured interviews from 5 students at the midpoint and after the submission of their capstone projects. The data were analyzed using reflexive thematic analysis. Our analysis of these data yielded eight themes that were then clustered into larger thematic categories of discourse judgments, implementation judgments, and framing judgments. Furthermore, we demonstrated that while in many educational and professional situations, discursive elements of practice are viewed as separate from technical elements, technical judgments are fully situated in and shaped by discursive practices. Our work suggests that more research is needed to both characterize the ways students acquire the discursive literacy required to practice engineering judgments and also to characterize the ways discursive literacy acquisition informs technical skill development.

In addition to these research findings, the PI was initiated into the engineering education research community through several avenues. First, the PI was mentored by the experienced engineering education Co-PI in the planning of qualitative research designs and reflexive thematic analysis. Second, this award enabled the PI to participate in the American Society of Engineering Education (ASEE) mentored journal reviewer program. This program involved several professional development resources focused on the critical evaluation of engineering education research reports, and networking opportunities with a focused small group of researchers that shared common methodological interests. This intentional exposure to engineering education research practice is a key outcome of the Research Initiation in Engineering Formation program.
